{{For|the designer of board games|Francis Tresham (game designer)}} {{Infobox gunpowder plot | name = Francis Tresham | image = FrancisTreshamPlotter.jpg | alt = Drawing | caption = Early 19th-century portrait of Tresham | enlisted = 14 October 1605 | role = Funding | captured = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{circa}} 1567 | birth_place = | death_date = 23 December 1605 (aged 37–38) | death_place = [[Tower of London]] | cause = [[Strangury]] | motive = [[Gunpowder plot]], a conspiracy to assassinate [[James I of England|King James VI & I]] and members of the [[Houses of Parliament]] | spouse = Anne Tufton | parents = Sir [[Thomas Tresham (died 1605)|Thomas Tresham]], Meriel Throckmorton | children = Lucy, Thomas, Elizabeth}}
'''Francis Tresham''' ({{circa}} 1567 – 23 December 1605), eldest son of [[Thomas Tresham (died 1605)|Thomas Tresham]] and Merial Throckmorton, was a member of the group of English provincial [[Catholic Church|Catholics]] who planned the failed [[Gunpowder Plot]] of 1605, a conspiracy to assassinate King [[James VI and I|James I of England]].
Tresham joined the [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex|Earl of Essex]]'s failed rebellion against the government in 1601, for which he was imprisoned. Only his family's intervention and his father's money saved him from [[attainder]]. Despite this, he became involved in two missions to Catholic Spain to seek support for English Catholics (then heavily persecuted), and finally with the Gunpowder Plotters.
According to his confession, Tresham joined the plot in October 1605. Its leader, [[Robert Catesby]], asked him to provide a large sum of money and the use of [[Rushton Hall]], but Tresham apparently provided neither, instead giving a much smaller amount of money to fellow plotter [[Thomas Wintour]]. Tresham also expressed concern that if the plot was successful, two of his brothers-in-law would be killed. An anonymous letter delivered to one of them, [[William Parker, 4th Baron Monteagle]], found its way to the [[Secretary of State (England)|English Secretary of State]], [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Robert Cecil]], an event which eventually proved decisive in the conspiracy's failure.
Historians have long suspected that Tresham wrote the letter, a hypothesis that remains unproven. Catesby and Wintour shared the same suspicion and threatened to kill him, but he was able to convince them otherwise. He was arrested on 12 November and confined to the [[Tower of London]]. In his confession, he sought to allay his involvement in the plot, but never mentioned the letter. He died of natural causes on 23 December 1605.
==Family and life before 1605== Born in about 1567, Francis Tresham was the eldest son of Sir [[Thomas Tresham (died 1605)|Thomas Tresham]], of [[Rushton Hall]] in [[Northamptonshire]], and Meriel Throckmorton, daughter of Sir [[Robert Throckmorton]] of Coughton in [[Warwickshire]].<ref name="ODNB Tresham">{{Citation |last=Nicholls |first=Mark |contribution=Tresham, Francis (1567?–1605) |title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |publisher=Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com |year=2004 |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/27708 |accessdate=16 November 2009 |doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/27708}}{{subscription}}</ref> According to the [[antiquary]] [[Anthony Wood (antiquary)|Anthony Wood]], Tresham was educated in [[Oxford]] at either [[St John's College, Oxford|St John's College]] or [[Worcester College, Oxford|Gloucester Hall]] or both,<ref>{{Harvnb|Wood|1813|pp=754–755}}</ref> although biographer Mark Nicholls mentions that there appears to be no other evidence to corroborate that claim.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> He married Anne Tufton, daughter of Sir John Tufton of Hothfield in Kent, in 1593. The couple had three children, twins Lucy and Thomas (b.1598), and Elizabeth. Thomas died in infancy, Lucy became a nun in Brussels, and Elizabeth married Sir George Heneage of Hainton, Lincolnshire.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/><ref name="Fraserp168">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=168}}</ref>
Tresham's father, born near the end of [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s reign, was regarded by the Catholic community as one of its leaders.<ref name="Fraserpxxviii">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=xxviii}}</ref> Thomas was received into the Catholic Church in 1580, and in the same year he allowed the Jesuit [[Edmund Campion]] to stay at his house in [[Hoxton]]. For the latter, following Campion's capture in 1581, he was tried in [[Star Chamber]]. Thomas's refusal to fully comply with his interrogators was the beginning of years of fines and spells in prison. He proclaimed the accession of [[James VI and I|James I]] to the English throne, but the king's promises to Thomas of forestry commissions and an end to [[recusancy]] fines were not kept. His finances were seriously depleted by fines of £7,720 for recusancy, and the spending of £12,200 on the marriages of six daughters meant that when he died in 1605, his estate was £11,500 in debt.<ref name="Fraserpxxviii"/><ref>{{Citation | last = Lock | first = Julian | contribution = Tresham, Sir Thomas (1543–1605) | title = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2009 | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/27712 | accessdate = 1 October 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/27712}}{{subscription}}</ref>
Author [[Antonia Fraser]] suggests that as a young man Francis became "resentful of his father's authority and profligate with his father's money."<ref name="Fraserp80">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=80}}</ref> Authors Peter Marshall and Geoffrey Scott describe him as possessing a "somewhat hot-headed nature",<ref>{{Harvnb|Marshall|Scott|2009|p=87}}</ref> while another source calls him a "wild unstayed man".<ref name="Haynesp80">{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|p=80}}</ref><!-- Haynes does not cite the source, presumably its an old text --> The Jesuit priest [[Oswald Tesimond]] wrote that he was "a man of sound judgement. He knew how to look after himself, but was not much to be trusted".<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> While still young he assaulted a man and his pregnant daughter, claiming that their family owed his father money. Tresham spent time in prison for this offence.<ref name="Fraserp80"/>
On 8 February 1601 he joined the [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex|Earl of Essex]] in open rebellion against the government.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=xxix}}</ref> Essex's aim was to secure his own ambitions, but the Jesuit [[Henry Garnet]] described the young men who accompanied him as being interested mostly in furthering the Catholic cause.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=58–59}}</ref> Captured and imprisoned, Tresham appealed to [[Thomas Howard, 1st Earl of Suffolk|Katherine Howard]], but was rebuked. His sister, Lady Mounteagle, alerted his cousin John Throckmorton, who turned to "three most honorable parsons and one especiall instrument" for help.<ref name="marshall87" /> The identity of these individuals is unclear, but Tresham was promised freedom on the condition that over the next three months his father pay £2,100 to William Ayloffe, to "save his lyef attainder in bloode."<ref name="marshall87">{{Harvnb|Marshall|Scott|2009|pp=87–88}}</ref> He was released on 21 June. The experience did not dissuade him from engaging in further conspiracies; in 1602 and 1603 he was involved in the missions to Catholic Spain made by [[Thomas Wintour]], Anthony Dutton (possibly an alias of [[John and Christopher Wright|Christopher Wright]])<ref>{{Citation | last = Nicholls | first = Mark | contribution = Wright, John (bap. 1568, d. 1605) | url = http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/30036/30028 | title = Oxford Dictionary of National Biography | publisher = Oxford University Press, hosted at oxforddnb.com | origyear = 2004 | year = 2008 | accessdate = 16 July 2010 | doi = 10.1093/ref:odnb/30028}}{{subscription}}</ref> and [[Guy Fawkes]], later dubbed by the English government as the Spanish Treason.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/><ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=61}}</ref> However, upon James's accession to the throne, he told Thomas Wintour (secretary to Tresham's brother-in-law [[William Parker, 4th Baron Monteagle]]), that he would "stand wholly for the King", and "to have no speech with him of Spain."<ref name="Fraserp168"/>
==Introduction== [[File:Rushton Hall 01.jpg|right|thumb|Rushton Hall]] English Catholics had hoped that the persecution of their faith would end when James succeeded [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]], as he appeared to hold more moderate views toward Catholics than his predecessor. But [[Robert Catesby]], a religious zealot also imprisoned for his involvement in the Essex rebellion, had grown tired of James's supposed perfidy and planned to kill the king. He hoped to achieve this by blowing up the [[Palace of Westminster#Old Palace|House of Lords]] with gunpowder and inciting a popular revolt to install James's daughter [[Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia|Princess Elizabeth]] as titular Queen.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=41–42}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Haynes | first = Alan | title = The Enduring Memory of the Gunpowder Plot | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/civil_war_revolution/gunpowder_haynes_01.shtml | publisher = bbc.co.uk | date = 5 November 2009 | accessdate = 14 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=140}}</ref>
Catesby had recruited 11 fellow Catholics to his cause but was running out of money. Even with his debts, with an annual income of over £3,000<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> Tresham was one of the wealthiest people known to the plotters,<ref name="Haynesp80"/> and Catesby's mother was Anne Throckmorton, an aunt of Tresham's. The two cousins had been raised together and shared a close relationship.<ref name="Fraserpp110111">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=110–111}}</ref>{{refn|In the opinion of author [[Antonia Fraser]], this closeness, and Catesby's domineering of his older cousin, proved crucial to Tresham joining the conspiracy.<ref name="Fraserpp110111"/>|group="nb"}}
Despite their shared upbringing and involvement in the Spanish Treason, the conspirators chose not to reveal the plot to him until 14 October 1605, shortly after his father died, and just weeks before the planned explosion.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> According to his confession, the meeting took place at the home of Tresham's brother-in-law, Lord Stourton, in [[Clerkenwell]]. Tresham claimed to have questioned Catesby on the morality of the plot, asking if it was spiritually "damnable". Catesby replied that it was not, at which point Tresham highlighted the danger that all Catholics would face should the plot succeed. Catesby replied, "The necessity of the Catholics" was such that "it must needs be done".<ref name="fraser167" /> He wanted two things from Tresham: £2,000, and the use of [[Rushton Hall]]; Catesby received neither. Tresham had no money to spare, his father's debts having reduced his inheritance,<ref name="fraser167">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=167–168}}</ref> although he paid a small sum{{refn|The sources used differ on the exact amount. Nicholls' claims it was "more than £190", while Fraser claims it was £100.|group="nb"}} to Thomas Wintour, on the understanding that the latter was to travel to the [[Low Countries]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=174}}</ref> Following the meeting, he hurried back to Rushton Hall and closed his household, taking care to hide family papers (not discovered until 1838).<ref>{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|pp=81–82}}</ref> He then returned to London with his mother and sisters,<ref name="Fraserpp173175">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=173–175}}</ref> and on 2 November acquired a licence to travel abroad with his servants and horses.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/>
==Monteagle letter== [[File:Monteagle letter.jpeg|thumb|alt=A damaged and aged piece of paper, or parchment, with multiple lines of handwritten English text.|An anonymous letter sent to William Parker, {{nowrap|4th Baron Monteagle}}, was instrumental in revealing the existence of the plot. The identity of its author has never been reliably established.]]
Later in October, during a meeting at which Tresham was present, the conspirators discussed the fates of several notable Catholic peers. Foremost in Tresham's thoughts were the lives of two brothers-in-law, [[William Parker, 4th Baron Monteagle]], and [[Edward Stourton, 10th Baron Stourton]], but Catesby proclaimed that "the innocent must perish with the guilty, sooner than ruin the chances of success."<ref>{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|p=82}}</ref> As the last few details were being finalised that month,<ref name="Fraser 1999 178–179">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=178–179}}</ref> on Saturday 26 October Monteagle received an anonymous letter while at his house in [[Hoxton]]. It contained the following message:
{{quote|My Lord, out of the love I bear to some of your friends, I have a care of your preservation. Therefore I would advise you, as you tender your life, to devise some excuse to shift your attendance at this parliament; for God and man hath concurred to punish the wickedness of this time. And think not slightly of this advertisement, but retire yourself into your country where you may expect the event in safety. For though there be no appearance of any stir, yet I say they shall receive a terrible blow this Parliament; and yet they shall not see who hurts them. This counsel is not to be condemned because it may do you good and can do you no harm; for the danger is passed as soon as you have burnt the letter. And I hope God will give you the grace to make good use of it, to whose holy protection I commend you.<ref name="Fraser 1999 178–179"/>}}
Uncertain of its meaning, Monteagle delivered it to the [[Secretary of State (England)|English Secretary of State]], [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Robert Cecil]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|p=89}}</ref>
Tresham has long been suspected as the letter's author. Mark Nicholls states that he almost certainly wrote it, pointing to the fact that once Catesby was made aware of its existence he immediately suspected Tresham and went with Thomas Wintour to confront him.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> The two threatened to "hang him", but "with such oaths and emphatic assertions" Tresham managed to convince the pair of his innocence, the next day urging them by letter to abandon the plot.<ref name="fraser180" /> Antonia Fraser suggests that Catesby and Wintour's decision to believe him should not be disregarded.<ref name="fraser180">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=180–182}}</ref> While making his deathbed confession in the [[Tower of London]], Tresham failed to mention the letter; an omission which in her opinion makes no sense if he is to be regarded as its author, especially considering that its recipient was by then being credited as the country's saviour.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=252}}</ref> Author Alan Haynes views Tresham as the most likely culprit, but raises the possibility that Cecil penned the letter himself, to protect a source.<ref>{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|p=88}}</ref>
==Revealed== Although he was already aware of certain stirrings even before he received the letter, Cecil did not yet know the exact nature of the plot or who was involved and had elected to watch to see what would happen.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=187–189}}</ref> When Monteagle's letter was shown to the king on Friday 1 November, James felt that it hinted at "some strategem of fire and powder",<ref>{{Harvnb|Northcote Parkinson|1976|p=70}}</ref> perhaps an explosion exceeding in violence the one that killed his father, [[Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley|Lord Darnley]], in 1567.<ref>{{Harvnb|Haynes|2005|p=90}}</ref><ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=193–194}}</ref> The following day, members of the Privy Council visited James to inform him that a search would be made of the Houses of Parliament, "both above and below".<ref name="fraser196" /> Meanwhile, Tresham again urged Catesby and Wintour to abandon the scheme, but his attempts were in vain. Fellow plotter [[Thomas Percy (Gunpowder Plot)|Thomas Percy]] said he was ready to "abide the uttermost trial",<ref name="fraser196">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=196–197}}</ref> and subsequently on 4 November Catesby and several others left London for the Midlands to prepare for the planned uprising.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=200}}</ref>
Fawkes was arrested while guarding the explosives shortly after midnight on 5 November 1605.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=201}}</ref> Calling himself John Johnson, he was at first interrogated by members of the King's Privy Chamber,<ref name="NorthcoteParkinsonpp9192">{{Harvnb|Northcote Parkinson|1976|pp=91–92}}</ref> but on 6 November James ordered that "John Johnson" be tortured.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=211}}</ref> His will finally broken, he revealed his true identity on 7 November, and on 8 November he began to name some of those with whom he was associated. Tresham's complicity was not revealed until the following day, although he was attributed with only a minor role.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=215–217, 228–229}}</ref> But while his compatriots had fled London the moment they discovered that Fawkes had been captured, Tresham had stayed in the city.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=204}}</ref> He was arrested on 12 November and transferred to the Tower three days later.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=236}}</ref> Catesby and several other plotters were killed on 8 November, during an armed siege at [[Holbeche House]] in [[Staffordshire]].<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=222–225}}</ref>
==Death== [[File:Tower of London, April 2006.jpg|right|thumb|Tresham died in the [[Tower of London]] from natural causes.]] Although at first he was uncooperative, on 13 November Tresham confessed to being involved in the plot, outlining his version of events to his interrogators. Moving his family from the safety of Rushton was, he pointed out, not the action of a man who believed he was taking them into "the very mouth and fury" of the plot.<ref name="Fraserpp173175"/> He admitted to the government that he was guilty only of the plot's concealment, denying that he had ever been an active member of the conspiracy, although by the end of the month he had also admitted his involvement in the Spanish Treason of 1602–1603.<ref name="ODNB Tresham"/> He claimed to have persuaded Thomas Wintour and Thomas Percy to postpone the explosion, and that he had planned to inform the king's secretary Thomas Lake of a "Puritan conspiracy".<ref name="Fraserpp173175"/> Fraser views much of his confession as "highly partial ... not only for his own sake but for that of his wife and children", and important in serving to highlight his unreliability.<ref name="Fraserpp173175"/>
Tresham suffered from a [[strangury]] caused by an inflammation of his urinary tract, and in December 1605 his health began to decline. Lieutenant of the Tower [[William Waad]], wondering if Tresham would live long enough for justice to take its course, described his condition as "worse and worse".<ref name="fraser250" /> Tresham preferred the services of a Dr Richard Foster over those of the Tower's regular doctor [[Matthew Gwinne]]; apparently Foster understood his case, indicating that it was not the first occasion on which he had treated him. During his last days he was attended by three more doctors and a nurse, along with William Vavasour, a rumoured illegitimate child of Thomas Tresham and possibly Francis's half-brother. As Tresham's wife, Anne, was apparently too upset, Vavasour wrote Tresham's deathbed confession and also an account of his last hours. Tresham apologised to the Jesuit priest [[Henry Garnet]] for implicating him in the Spanish Treason, and used the rest of his deathbed confession to protest his innocence. Anne and William read prayers at his bedside; he died at 2:00 am on 23 December. Despite not being tried, his head joined those of Catesby and Percy on display at Northampton, while his body was thrown into a hole at [[Tower Hill]]. His estates passed to his brother Lewis. Tresham's apology never reached its intended target,<ref name="fraser250">{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=250–253}}</ref> and his letter, along with the discovery of Garnet's ''Of Equivocation'',<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|p=268}}</ref> found among the "heretical, treasonable and damnable books" at Tresham's chamber in the [[Inner Temple]], was used to great effect by Sir [[Edward Coke]] in Garnet's trial.<ref>{{Harvnb|Fraser|2005|pp=290, 311–315}}</ref> The priest was executed in May 1606.<ref>{{Harvnb|Northcote Parkinson|1976|pp=114–115}}</ref>

page.title: From the Diary of Virginia Woolf

revision.text:
'''''From the Diary of Virginia Woolf''''' is an eight-part [[song cycle]] written by [[Dominick Argento]] in 1974 for the English [[mezzo-soprano]] [[Janet Baker]].{{cite web|title=TBD|url=http://www.allmusic.com/composition/from-the-diary-of-virginia-woolf-for-voice-piano-mc0002378934|website=All Music|publisher=All Media Network, LLC|accessdate=7 November 2015}} The work won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]] in 1975. The text of the songs comes from ''A Writer's Diary: Being Extracts from the Diary of Virginia Woolf'', which was published in 1954.{{cite web|title=TBD|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0026QY6OM|publisher=Amazon.com Inc.|accessdate=7 November 2015}} (The five-volume diaries edited by Anne Olivier Bell were not published until 1979.{{cite web|title=TBD|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000IDBR4M|website=Amazon.com|publisher=Amazon.com Inc.|accessdate=7 November 2015}})
The choice of a prose, rather than poetic, source for a text is a common theme for Argento, who did the same thing in his cycles ''Letters from Composers'', ''The Andrée Expedition'', and ''Casa Guidi''. In each case, he captures the cadence and flow of these more free-form writings without sacrificing musical structure or melodic interest. The composer's original intention was to use excerpts from Woolf's novel ''The Waves'' as the basis for his cycle. But in reading her newly published diaries he discovered a source much richer in musical and expressive possibilities. The highly confessional diary texts illuminate Woolf's inner world in a more immediate way than do her literary works.
== Movements == # The Diary # Anxiety # Fancy # Hardy's Funeral # Rome # War # Parents # Last Entry Assertion{{cite web|last1=Woods|first1=Noelle|title=Reflections of a Life: Biographical Perspectives of Virginia Woolf Illuminated by the Music and Drama of Dominick Argento's Song Cycle, "From the Diary of Virginia Woolf"|url=https://etd.ohiolink.edu/!etd.send_file?accession=osu1132158619&disposition=inline|publisher=Ohio State University|accessdate=6 November 2015|date=1996}} Assertion{{cite web|last1=Matava|first1=Jacquelyn|title=Dominick Argento's "From the Diary of Virginia Woolf": A Preparation Guide for Performers|url=https://scholarworks.iu.edu/dspace/bitstream/handle/2022/17542/Matava_Jacquelyn_2014.pdf?sequence=1|website=TBD|publisher=Indiana University|accessdate=6 November 2015|format=PDF|date=2014}} == Recordings == * https://www.amazon.com/Diary-Virginia-Woolf-Janet-Baker/dp/B000003YNN/ref=sr_1_1?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1446884057&sr=1-1&keywords=From+the+Diary+of+Virginia+Woolf * https://www.amazon.com/Argento-Diary-Virginia-Woolf-Benson/dp/B000GHTGLG/ref=sr_1_2?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1446884057&sr=1-2&keywords=From+the+Diary+of+Virginia+Woolf * https://www.amazon.com/D-Argento-Virginia-Andr%C3%A9e-Expedition/dp/B00J849APU/ref=sr_1_3?s=music&ie=UTF8&qid=1446884057&sr=1-3&keywords=From+the+Diary+of+Virginia+Woolf Score available from http://www.boosey.com/shop/prod/Dominick-Argento-From-The-Diary-of-Virginia-Woolf-voice-piano-Medium-Voice-Piano/600978 ==References== {{reflist}} {{Virginia Woolf}} {{PulitzerPrize Music 1971–1980|state=expanded}} {{italic title}} [[Category:Compositions by Dominick Argento]] [[Category:1974 compositions]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Virginia Woolf]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Music-winning works]] [[Category:Classical song cycles in English]] [[Category:Works based on diaries]]

:''This article only provides a detailed description of the financial market events of November 2008. For the background information, causes, effects and policy responses see [[Financial crisis of 2007-08]]. For a timeline see [[Subprime crisis impact timeline]].
==Week of November 2==
===Reports of economic activity=== October sales of cars and light trucks in the United States fell precipitously in 2008 when compared with sales in October 2007, with General Motors falling 45%, Ford falling 30%, Chrysler falling 35%, Toyota falling 23%, Honda falling 25%, and Nissan falling 33%. Much of the falloff in sales was attributable to customers being unable to arrange financing.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/04/business/04auto.html |title=Automakers Report Grim October Sales |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-03 |accessdate=2008-11-04 |first=Bill |last=Vlasic |author2=Nick Bunkley }}</ref> Except for Wal-Mart, which posted a slight gain, retail sales were off during October 2008 as compared with October 2007 in the United States with some moderate priced stores reporting double digit decreases.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/07/business/07shop.html |title=Retailers See a Broad Slowdown Ahead of Holidays |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2008-11-06 |first=Stephanie |last=Rosenbloom }}</ref> October retail sales were down 4.1% from October 2007 and down 2.8% from September 2008 with sales of cars and auto parts leading the way with a 23.4% decline from October 2007, and a 31.9% decline from September 2008.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/15/business/economy/15econ.html |title=A Record Decline in October’s Retail Sales |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-14 |accessdate=2008-11-14 |first=Jack |last=Healy }}</ref>
Employment reports released by the Labor Department on Friday, November 7, showed that about 500,000 jobs were lost in the United States during September and October 2008 with unemployment rising to 6.5% at the end of October. The September figure was revised to 284,000 from the initial 159,000 reported. The initial October figure was 240,000. This is a substantial acceleration from the average 75,000 jobs lost each month since the beginning of 2008. It is anticipated by experts that unemployment will rise to 8% by the middle of 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/08/business/economy/08econ.html |title=Unemployment Rate at 14-Year High After Big October Losses |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-07 |accessdate=2008-11-07 |first=Peter S. |last=Goodman |author2=Michael M. Grynbaum }}</ref>
In the UK car sales fell by 23% in October, following a 21% decline in September.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/article5095706.ece |title=Car sales tumble to worst decline since 1991 |publisher=The Times |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2008-11-06 |first=Dan |last=Sabbagh | location=London}}</ref>
===Events=== Amid predictions of a "deep recession" in the UK and the Eurozone,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article5093771.ece |title=Deep and lengthy recession takes shape as UK output figures shrink |publisher=The Times |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2008-11-06 |first=Gary |last=Duncan | location=London}}</ref> on Thursday, November 6, the [[Bank of England]], citing a reduced danger of inflation due to falling commodities prices, lowered its base rate by 1.5 percentage points, from 4.5% to 3%.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article5096373.ece |title=Bank of England cuts interest rate by 1.5% to 54-year low |publisher=The Times |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2008-11-06 |first=Gary |last=Duncan |author2=Grainne Gilmore | location=London}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/news/2008/076.htm "Bank of England Reduces Bank Rate by 1.5 Percentage Points to 3%"] News Release by the Bank of England November 6, 2008</ref> This was accompanied by a 50 basis point drop in the base rate to 3.25% by the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/article5098413.ece |title=Europe cuts interest rate to 3.25% |publisher=The Times |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2008-11-06 |first=Gary |last=Duncan |author2=Grainne Gilmore | location=London}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ecb.int/press/pressconf/2008/html/is081106.en.html Introductory statement at press conference, Jean-Claude Trichet, President of the ECB, Lucas Papademos, Vice President of the ECB] Frankfurt am Main, November 6, 2008</ref>
On November 6, the [[International Monetary Fund]] (IMF) at Washington, D.C., predicted for 2009 a worldwide −0.3% decrease of the BIP for the developed economies (−0.7% for the USA and −0.8% for Germany).<ref>[http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/weorepts.htm News Release by the IMF, November 6, 2008]</ref>
==Week of November 9== [[Image:Bush-manhattan-institute.jpg|thumb|300px|[[George W. Bush]] addressing a [[Manhattan Institute]]-sponsored event at [[Federal Hall National Memorial]] on November 13, 2008, speaking against too much government involvement in resolving the crisis.]] On Sunday, November 9, the People's Republic of China announced a [[China Stimulus Plan|$586 billion domestic stimulus package]] for the remainder of 2008, 2009, and 2010. Economic growth has slowed in China with sharp drops in property and stock values.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/10/world/asia/10china.html |title=China Unveils $586 Billion Economic Stimulus Plan| date=2008-11-09| accessdate=2008-11-09|first=David|last=Barboza | work=The New York Times}}</ref> The money from the stimulus package will be spent on upgrading infrastructure, particularly roads, railways, airports and the power grids throughout the country and raise rural incomes via land reform. Also spending will be made on social welfare projects such as affordable housing and environmental protection.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/2008/11/09/china-stimulus-economy-biz-cx_pm_1109notes.html |title=China Announces Massive Stimulus Package |publisher=Forbes.com |author=Paul Maidment |accessdate=2008-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081112053515/http://www.forbes.com/business/2008/11/09/china-stimulus-economy-biz-cx_pm_1109notes.html |archivedate=November 12, 2008 }} </ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/11/10/asia/10china.php |title=China unveils $586 billion stimulus plan|publisher=International Herald Tribune |author=David Barboza|accessdate=2008-11-10}}</ref> Some Chinese factories engaged in low-end export manufacturing have gone out of business.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/world/asia/14china.html |title=Factories Shut, China Workers Are Suffering |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-13 |accessdate=2008-11-14 |first=Edward |last=Wong }}</ref>
On Monday, November 10, the US Treasury announced investment of 40 billion dollars in preferred stock of AIG, adjusting the terms of the existing credit line and its amount. Total exposure, including equity and debt, is now 150 billion dollars. Funds were drawn from the Troubled Asset Relief Program which was not available at the time of the original bailout of AIG.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/11/business/economy/11aig.html |title=U.S. Provides More Aid to Big Insurer| date=2008-11-10| accessdate=2008-11-10|first=Andrew Ross|last=Sorkin | work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref>[http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/other/20081110a.htm Press release Federal Reserve regarding restructuring of the AIG bailout, November 10, 2008]</ref> The question of whether emergency funding would be made available to the [[Automotive industry crisis of 2008|troubled American auto industry]] remained under consideration. [[General Motors]] is the most threatened with a sharp drop in sales and diminishing cash reserves.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/08/business/08auto.html|title=G.M. Says U.S. Cash Is Its Best Hope| date=2008-11-07| accessdate=2008-11-10|first=Bill|last=Vlasic | work=The New York Times}}</ref>
On Wednesday, November 12, US Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson scrapped the original Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) and announced shift in the focus to consumer lending. The remaining portion of the TARP budget will be used to help relieve pressure on consumer credits such as car loans, student loans, credit cards etc.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aoD4QebIb_Fo&refer=home |title=Paulson Shifts Focus of Rescue to Consumer Lending| date=2008-11-12| accessdate=2008-11-12|work=Bloomberg}}</ref>
On Thursday November 13, the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] marked another dramatic session, with the index (opening at 8,282.66) that after a mixed start tumbled again below the 8,000 mark (to a low of 7,965.42) but then reversed the trend and gained more than 900 points (fourth largest daily swing ever) in less than three hours closing at 8,835.25 with a net gain of more than 550 points (third largest ever).
The prospect of a federal bailout of failing US automakers appeared dim pending the inauguration of Barack Obama. There appeared to be opposition from both the Republican members of the Senate and the office of the incumbent president, George W. Bush, which expressed doubt that the companies could be salvaged.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/14/business/14auto.html |title=Chances Dwindle on Bailout Plan for Automakers |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-13 |accessdate=2008-11-14 |first=David M. |last=Herszenhorn }}</ref>
At the invitation of US President George W. Bush the leaders of the [[G-20]] held the initial session of the [[2008 G-20 Washington summit|Summit on Financial Markets and the World Economy]] on Saturday, November 15, in Washington, D.C. They agreed to cooperate with respect to the global financial crisis and issued a statement regarding immediate and medium term goals and actions considered necessary to support and reform the international economy. The next session will be held April 30, probably in London, after Barack Obama takes office as President of the United States. The initial session, attended by the leaders of the G-20 set forth a road map of proposed reforms which will be followed up in coming months by the development of specific proposals, including a comprehensive reform of the Bretton Woods Institutions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/16/business/worldbusiness/16summit.html |title=World Leaders Vow Joint Push to Aid Economy |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-15 |accessdate=2008-11-15 |first=Mark |last=Landler }}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/16/washington/summit-text.html "Statement From G-20 Summit"] November 15, 2008</ref>
==Week of November 16==
===Reports of economic activity=== In the third quarter of 2008 the gross domestic product of Japan fell 0.4% following a 3.7% drop in the second quarter. Similar reports of recession level economic activity had been released previously by Hong Kong, Germany and the European Union.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/17/business/worldbusiness/17yen.html |title=Japan’s Economy, World’s Second Largest, Is in Recession |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-16 |accessdate=2008-11-16 |first=Martin |last=Fackler }}</ref>
It was widely anticipated that economic activity in the United States would be found to be at recession levels when statistics were released.<ref>[http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/2008/survq408.cfm "Fourth Quarter 2008 Survey of Professional Forecasters"] Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, October 17, 2008</ref> As of November 20 new applications for unemployment benefits rose to a seasonally adjusted 542,000 per week; new applications averaged over 500,000 a week for the last four weeks.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/21/business/economy/21econ.html |title=New Jobless Claims Reach a 16-Year High, U.S. Says |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2008-11-20 |first= |last=Associated Press }}</ref>
===Events=== On Wednesday, November 19, proposed federal bailouts of US auto makers failed with Republican senators rejecting the Democratic plan and Democratic senators rejecting the Republican plan.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/20/business/20auto.html |title=Auto Chiefs Fail to Get Bailout Aid |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2008-11-19 |first=Bill |last=Vlasic |author2=David M. Herszenhorn }}</ref> Negotiations continued with the Democrats requesting a plan for viability from the automakers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/21/business/21auto.html |title=Democrats Ask Automakers for Way Forward |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2008-11-20 |first=David M. |last=Herszenhorn }}</ref> Automobile sales were also down sharply in Europe and bailouts were under consideration, particularly for subsidiaries of General Motors such as Opel in Germany<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/autos/2008-11-20-europe-automakers-bailout_N.htm |title=Automakers in Europe also look for bailout |publisher=USA Today |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2008-11-21 |first= |last=Reuters |author2=Caroline Jacobs |author3=Gernot Heller }}</ref> and Vauxhall in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/engineering/article5202036.ece |title=CBI chief Richard Lambert opposes big bailout for carmakers |publisher=The Times |date=2008-11-21 |accessdate=2008-11-21 |first=Christine |last=Buckley | location=London}}</ref>
On Wednesday, November 19, the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] fell sharply by 427.47 points or 5.07%, closing below 8,000 points for the first time since March 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/11/19/markets/markets_newyork/index.htm?postversion=2008111916|title=Dow below 8,000 - 1st time since '03 | work=CNN | date=2008-11-19 | accessdate=2010-05-03 | first=Ben | last=Rooney}}</ref> United States financial stocks led the way with [[Citigroup]] showing a 23% drop.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/20/business/economy/20markets.html |title=Shares Near 6-Year Low, With More Losses Feared |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2008-11-19 |first=Jack |last=Healy }}</ref> The UK [[FTSE100]] fell by about the same percentage, closing just above 4000. The [[BBC Global 30]], combining Europe, Asia and North America in a single index, fell by 5.1%.
On Thursday, November 20 the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 445 points in the last minutes of the trading session, closing at 7,552, the lowest point in six years. Shares in Citigroup plummeted another 26%, and shares of other major US financial institutions dropped by more than 10%.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/21/business/21markets.html |title=Markets Dive in Last Hour, Carving New Lows |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2008-11-20 |first=Jack |last=Healy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/21/business/21finance.html |title=Citigroup Tries to Stop the Drop in Its Share Price |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2008-11-20 |first=Eric |last=Dash |author2=Lousie Story }}</ref>
On Friday, November 21 the Dow Jones Industrial Average recovered about half of the loss for the week and closed above 8,000; however, stocks of Citibank, Bank of America, and J.P. Morgan Chase continued to decline.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/22/business/22markets.html |title=Stocks Soar in Late Trading |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-21 |accessdate=2008-11-21 |first=Jack |last=Healy }}</ref> It was unclear whether the drop in the value of [[Citigroup]] stock to under $4 reflected financial weakness of the bank or what rescue plan could be crafted.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/22/business/22citi.html |title=Citigroup, Under Siege, Holds Talks With U.S. |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-21 |accessdate=2008-11-21 |first=Andrew Ross |last=Sorkin |author2=Louise Story }}</ref> One theory for the disappointment of investors was that the failure of the Treasury to purchase toxic mortgage related securities held by the bank left billions of unrealized losses on the books.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/22/business/22bank.html |title=Woes at Citigroup Began With Failed Bid for Wachovia |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-22 |accessdate=2008-11-22 |first=Ben |last=White |author2=Vikas Bajaj }}</ref> Citigroup continues to hold $20 billion in mortgage-related securities, currently valued at a substantial discount.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/23/business/23citi.html |title=Citigroup Pays for a Rush to Risk |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-11-22 |accessdate=2008-11-22 |first=Eric |last=Dash |author2=Julie Creswell }}</ref>
As of the week of November 16 stock losses in United States markets during 2008 as measured by the [[S&P 500]] were equivalent to those suffered in 1931, over 50%.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/22/business/22charts.html | title=And You Thought 1931 Was Bad for the Market | publisher=The New York Times | date=2008-11-22 | accessdate=2008-11-22 | first=Floyd | last=Norris }}</ref> Total losses during the Great Depression exceeded 80% but that was over a three-year period.
==Week of November 23== Late on Sunday, November 23, a rescue plan for Citigroup was agreed by the United States government. In a joint statement by the [[United States Treasury Department]], the [[Federal Reserve]] and the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corp]] it was announced that in exchange for preferred stock valued at $27 billion paying 8% interest, a further $20 billion would be invested into the company and that the government would limit loss on $306 billion in risky loans and securities to 29 billion dollars plus 10% of any remaining losses.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/24/business/24citibank.html | title=U.S. Approves Plan to Help Citigroup Cope With Losses | publisher=The New York Times | date=2008-11-23 | accessdate=2008-11-24 | first=Eric | last=Dash }}</ref> According to the joint statement, "With these transactions, the U.S. government is taking the actions necessary to strengthen the financial system and protect U.S. taxpayers and the U.S. economy."<ref>[http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/081124/citigroup.html Government unveils bold plan to rescue Citigroup. Associated Press. Retrieved November 24, 2008.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204000000/http://biz.yahoo.com/ap/081124/citigroup.html |date=December 4, 2008 }}</ref>
Friday, November 21 and Monday, November 24 marked the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]]'s largest two-session gain since October 1987. The Dow gained 891.10 points, 11.8%, bringing it to a close at 8,443.39 points.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/11/24/markets/markets_newyork/index.htm?postversion=2008112415|title=Dow's biggest 2-day run since '87 | work=CNN | date=2008-11-24 | accessdate=2010-05-03 | first=Alexandra | last=Twin}}</ref>
